author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a little fat comfortable grey squirrel, called Timmy Tiptoes.

author: Potter
text: He had a nest thatched with leaves in the top of a tall tree; and he had a little squirrel wife called Goody.

author: Potter
text: Timmy Tiptoes sat out, enjoying the breeze; he whisked his tail and chuckled--"Little wife Goody, the nuts are ripe; we must lay up a store for winter and spring."

author: Potter
text: Goody Tiptoes was busy pushing moss under the thatch--"The nest is so snug, we shall be sound asleep all winter."

author: Potter
text: "Then we shall wake up all the thinner, when there is nothing to eat in spring- time," replied prudent Timothy.

author: Potter
text: When Timmy and Goody Tiptoes came to the nut thicket, they found other squirrels were there already.

author: Potter
text: Timmy took off his jacket and hung it on a twig; they worked away quietly by themselves.

author: Potter
text: Every day they made several journeys and picked quantities of nuts.

author: Potter
text: They carried them away in bags, and stored them in several hollow stumps near the tree where they had built their nest.

author: Potter
text: When these stumps were full, they began to empty the bags into a hole high up a tree, that had belonged to a woodpecker; the nuts rattled down--down--down inside.

author: Potter
text: "How shall you ever get them out again?

author: Potter
text: It is like a money box!" said Goody.

author: Potter
text: "I shall be much thinner before springtime, my love," said Timmy Tiptoes, peeping into the hole.

author: Potter
text: They did collect quantities-- because they did not lose them!

author: Potter
text: Squirrels who bury their nuts in the ground lose more than half, because they cannot remember the place.

author: Potter
text: The most forgetful squirrel in the wood was called Silvertail.

author: Potter
text: He began to dig, and he could not remember.

author: Potter
text: And then he dug again and found some nuts that did not belong to him; and there was a fight.

author: Potter
text: And other squirrels began to dig,--the whole wood was in commotion!

author: Potter
text: Unfortunately, just at this time a flock of little birds flew by, from bush to bush, searching for green caterpillars and spiders.

author: Potter
text: There were several sorts of little birds, twittering different songs.

author: Potter
text: The first one sang--"Who's bin digging-up MY nuts?

author: Potter
text: Who's-been- digging-up MY nuts?"

author: Potter
text: And another sang--"Little bita bread and-NO-cheese!

author: Potter
text: Little bit-a- bread an'-NO-cheese!"

author: Potter
text: The squirrels followed and listened.

author: Potter
text: The first little bird flew into the bush where Timmy and Goody Tiptoes were quietly tying up their bags, and it sang--"Who's-bin digging-up MY nuts?

author: Potter
text: Who's been digging-up MY-nuts?"

author: Potter
text: Timmy Tiptoes went on with his work without replying; indeed, the little bird did not expect an answer.

author: Potter
text: It was only singing its natural song, and it meant nothing at all.

author: Potter
text: But when the other squirrels heard that song, they rushed upon Timmy Tiptoes and cuffed and scratched him, and upset his bag of nuts.

author: Potter
text: The innocent little bird which had caused all the mischief, flew away in a fright!

author: Potter
text: Timmy rolled over and over, and then turned tail and fled towards his nest, followed by a crowd of squirrels shouting-- "Who's-been digging-up MY-nuts?"

author: Potter
text: They caught him and dragged him up the very same tree, where there was the little round hole, and they pushed him in.

author: Potter
text: The hole was much too small for Timmy Tiptoes' figure.

author: Potter
text: They squeezed him dreadfully, it was a wonder they did not break his ribs.

author: Potter
text: "We will leave him here till he confesses," said Silvertail Squirrel and he shouted into the hole--"Who's- been-digging-up MY-nuts?"

author: Potter
text: Timmy Tiptoes made no reply; he had tumbled down inside the tree, upon half a peck of nuts belonging to himself.

author: Potter
text: He lay quite stunned and still.

author: Potter
text: Goody Tiptoes picked up the nut bags and went home.

author: Potter
text: She made a cup of tea for Timmy; but he didn't come and didn't come.

author: Potter
text: Goody Tiptoes passed a lonely and unhappy night.

author: Potter
text: Next morning she ventured back to the nut bushes to look for him; but the other unkind squirrels drove her away.

author: Potter
text: She wandered all over the wood, calling--

author: Potter
text: "Timmy Tiptoes!

author: Potter
text: Timmy Tip- toes!

author: Potter
text: Oh, where is Timmy Tiptoes?"

author: Potter
text: In the meantime Timmy Tiptoes came to his senses.

author: Potter
text: He found himself tucked up in a little moss bed, very much in the dark, feeling sore; it seemed to be under ground.

author: Potter
text: Timmy coughed and groaned, because his ribs hurted him.

author: Potter
text: There was a chirpy noise, and a small striped Chipmunk appeared with a night light, and hoped he felt better?

author: Potter
text: It was most kind to Timmy Tiptoes; it lent him its nightcap; and the house was full of provisions.

author: Potter
text: The Chipmunk explained that it had rained nuts through the top of the tree--"Besides, I found a few buried!"

author: Potter
text: It laughed and chuckled when it heard Timmy's story.

author: Potter
text: While Timmy was confined to bed, it 'ticed him to eat quantities --"But how shall I ever get out through that hole unless I thin myself?

author: Potter
text: My wife will be anxious!"

author: Potter
text: "Just another nut--or two nuts; let me crack them for you," said the Chipmunk.

author: Potter
text: Timmy Tiptoes grew fatter and fatter!

author: Potter
text: Now Goody Tiptoes had set to work again by herself.

author: Potter
text: She did not put any more nuts into the woodpecker's hole, because she had always doubted how they could be got out again.

author: Potter
text: She hid them under a tree root; they rattled down, down, down.

author: Potter
text: Once when Goody emptied an extra big bagful, there was a decided squeak; and next time Goody brought another bagful, a little striped Chipmunk scrambled out in a hurry.

author: Potter
text: "It is getting perfectly full-up downstairs; the sitting room is full, and they are rolling along the passage; and my husband, Chippy Hackee, has run away and left me.

author: Potter
text: What is the explanation of these showers of nuts?"

author: Potter
text: "I am sure I beg your pardon; I did not know that anybody lived here," said Mrs. Goody Tiptoes; "but where is Chippy Hackee?

author: Potter
text: My husband, Timmy Tiptoes, has run away too."

author: Potter
text: "I know where Chippy is; a little bird told me," said Mrs. Chippy Hackee.

author: Potter
text: She led the way to the woodpecker's tree, and they listened at the hole.

author: Potter
text: Down below there was a noise of nutcrackers, and a fat squirrel voice and a thin squirrel voice were singing together--

author: Potter
text: "My little old man and I fell out, How shall we bring this matter about?

author: Potter
text: Bring it about as well as you can, And get you gone, you little old man!"

author: Potter
text: "You could squeeze in, through that little round hole," said Goody Tiptoes.

author: Potter
text: "Yes, I could," said the Chipmunk, "but my husband, Chippy Hackee, bites!"

author: Potter
text: Down below there was a noise of cracking nuts and nibbling; and then the fat squirrel voice and the thin squirrel voice sang--

author: Potter
text: "For the diddlum day Day diddle durn di!

author: Potter
text: Day diddle diddle dum day!"

author: Potter
text: Then Goody peeped in at the hole, and called down--"Timmy Tiptoes!

author: Potter
text: Oh fie, Timmy Tiptoes!"

author: Potter
text: And Timmy replied, "Is that you, Goody Tiptoes?

author: Potter
text: Why, certainly!"

author: Potter
text: He came up and kissed Goody through the hole; but he was so fat that he could not get out.

author: Potter
text: Chippy Hackee was not too fat, but he did not want to come; he stayed down below and chuckled.

author: Potter
text: And so it went on for a fort- night; till a big wind blew off the top of the tree, and opened up the hole and let in the rain.

author: Potter
text: Then Timmy Tiptoes came out, and went home with an umbrella.

author: Potter
text: But Chippy Hackee continued to camp out for another week, although it was uncomfortable.

author: Potter
text: At last a large bear came walking through the wood.

author: Potter
text: Perhaps he also was looking for nuts; he seemed to be sniffing around.

author: Potter
text: Chippy Hackee went home in a hurry!

author: Potter
text: And when Chippy Hackee got home, he found he had caught a cold in his head; and he was more uncomfortable still.

author: Potter
text: And now Timmy and Goody Tiptoes keep their nut store fastened up with a little padlock.

author: Potter
text: And whenever that little bird sees the Chipmunks, he sings--"Who's-been-digging- up MY-nuts?

author: Potter
text: Who's been dig- ging-up MY-nuts?"

author: Potter
text: But nobody ever answers!
